Then for any indices i < j < k we have:
  aᵢ = A + (i – 1)d,
  aⱼ = A + (j – 1)d,
  aₖ = A + (k – 1)d.
The condition for (aᵢ, aⱼ, aₖ) to be an arithmetic progression is
  2·[A + (j – 1)d] = [A + (i – 1)d] + [A + (k – 1)d].
Working out the algebra,
  2A + 2(j – 1)d = 2A + (i + k – 2)d,
so we must have
  2(j – 1) = (i + k – 2)
    or  2j = i + k.
Thus, in an arithmetic progression, a triple (i, j, k) forms an AP if and only if j is exactly the average of i and k, which means that i + k must be even and then j = (i + k)/2.

text: One might wonder if there is another way to assign n distinct reals in increasing order such that there are more 3‐term arithmetic progressions than in the arithmetic progression case. The key observation is that for any increasing sequence, if a triple (aᵢ, aⱼ, aₖ) is to form a three‐term AP, then the indices i, j, and k must satisfy 2aⱼ = aᵢ + aₖ. In an arithmetic progression the relation 2aⱼ = aᵢ + aₖ is “automatically” forced by the equal spacing. In a non‐arithmetic progression, there is less “structure” and the chance that 2aⱼ equals aᵢ + aₖ for any given three indices is even smaller. In fact, one can show that the arithmetic progression maximizes the number of solutions to 2aⱼ = aᵢ + aₖ.
